raw_text: Some of them are Frequency, Point-wise mutual information (Church and Hanks, 1989), Distributed frequency of object (Tapanainen et al, 1998), Distributed frequency of object using verb information (Venkatapathyand Joshi, 2005), Similarity of object in verb object pair using the LSA model (Baldwin et al,2003), (Venkatapathy and Joshi, 2005) and Lexical and Syntactic fixedness (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006)
clean_text: Some of them are Frequency, Point-wise mutual information (Church and Hanks, 1989), Distributed frequency of object (Tapanainen et al, 1998), Distributed frequency of object using verb information (Venkatapathy and Joshi, 2005), Similarity of object in verb object pair using the LSA model (Baldwin et al, 2003), (Venkatapathy and Joshi, 2005) and Lexical and Syntactic fixedness (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006).

raw_text: Anotherwork uses both the syntactic and the lexical fixedness of VNICs in order to distinguish them from non-idiomatic ones, and eventually to extract them from corpora (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006)
clean_text: Another work uses both the syntactic and the lexical fixedness of VNICs in order to distinguish them from non-idiomatic ones, and eventually to extract them from corpora (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006).

raw_text: To measure fixedness, we use statistical measures of lexical, syntactic, and overall fixedness that we have developed in a previous study (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006), as well as some new measures we introduce here
clean_text: To measure fixedness, we use statistical measures of lexical, syntactic, and overall fixedness that we have developed in a previous study (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006), as well as some new measures we introduce here.

raw_text: We focus here on phrases that allow some syntactic variation, but do not allow other kinds. The small amount of previous work on the identification of syntactic fixedness (Wermter and Hahn (2004), Fazly and Stevenson (2006)) has either focused on a single variation variety, or has only been evaluated for combinations of a small preselected list of words, presumably due to noise
clean_text: The small amount of previous work on the identification of syntactic fixedness (Wermter and Hahn (2004), Fazly and Stevenson (2006)) has either focused on a single variation variety, or has only been evaluated for combinations of a small preselected list of words, presumably due to noise.

raw_text: Fazly and Stevenson (2006) propose a measure for detecting the syntactic fixedness of English verb phrases of the same variety as us
clean_text: Fazly and Stevenson (2006) propose a measure for detecting the syntactic fixedness of English verb phrases of the same variety as us.

raw_text: Fazly and Stevenson (2006) combine information about syntactic and lexical fixedness (i.e., estimated degree of compositionality) into one measure
clean_text: Fazly and Stevenson (2006) combine information about syntactic and lexical fixedness (i.e., estimated degree of compositionality) into one measure.

citing_paper_authors: Carlos, Ramisch | Aline, Villavicencio | Leonardo, Moura | Marco, Idiart
raw_text: In particular, Fazlyand Stevenson (2006) look at the correlation between syntactic fixedness (in terms of e.g .passivisation, choice of determiner type and pluralisation) and non-compositionality of verb-noun com pounds such as shoot the breeze. In this work we investigate the automatic extraction of VPCs, looking into a variety of methods, combining linguistic with statistical information, ranging from frequencies to association measures: Mutual Information (MI),? 2 and Entropy
clean_text: In particular, Fazly and Stevenson (2006) look at the correlation between syntactic fixedness (in terms of e.g. passivisation, choice of determiner type and pluralisation) and non-compositionality of verb-noun compounds such as shoot the breeze.

raw_text: In their work on automatically identifying idiom types, Fazly and Stevenson (2006)? henceforth FS06? show that an idiomatic VNC tends to have one (or at most a small number of) canonical form (s), which are its most preferred syntactic patterns

raw_text: In a previous study (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006), the authors came up with a dozen possible syntactic forms for verb-object pairs (based on passivization, determiner, and object pluralization) and used a corpus based statistical measure to determine the canonical form (s)
clean_text: In a previous study (Fazly and Stevenson, 2006), the authors came up with a dozen possible syntactic forms for verb-object pairs (based on passivization, determiner, and object pluralization) and used a corpus based statistical measure to determine the canonical form (s).
